summary: Privilege escalation with SageMaker and there's more hiding in execution roles (10 minute read) Privilege escalation flaws have been discovered in AWS SageMaker. Attackers with specific permissions can inject malicious code via lifecycle configurations, mimicking EC2 user data escalation and affecting Lambda and CloudFormation. It is important to detect stop-modify-start sequences in CloudTrail and implement strict access controls.

title: The End of the Train-Test Split
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-02, Reading time: 13 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Ffolio.benguzovsky.com%2Ftrain-test%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019adf6cef0e-391161ea-3c75-4db1-9d24-f8b7fdfff6d2-000000/GMsNUZVACaxs45ePYhY1wUmAZh8IVmQq4OjjJ5ovtME=434
summary: The End of the Train-Test Split (13 minute read) Models don't know what is 'out of distribution' for themselves. Engineers will always be required in the loop until this problem is solved. title: How Can Interpretability Researchers Help AGI Go Well?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-02, Reading time: 32 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.alignmentforum.org%2Fposts%2FMnkeepcGirnJn736j%2Fhow-can-interpretability-researchers-help-agi-go-well%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019adf6cef0e-391161ea-3c75-4db1-9d24-f8b7fdfff6d2-000000/-5RKAfgrD5QMIvhmlWzhoV61SDbjKL755vT_ab5yGaE=434
summary: How Can Interpretability Researchers Help AGI Go Well? (32 minute read) The Google DeepMind mechanistic interpretability team has pivoted to a pragmatic approach to interpretability over the last year. It is important to have empirical feedback on goals with good proxy tasks. Near-complete understanding isn't required for significant impact. Good focused projects start with a theory of change, and good exploratory projects start with a robustly useful setting.

title: 100,000 TPS over a billion rows: the unreasonable effectiveness of SQLite
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-03, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fandersmurphy.com%2F2025%2F12%2F02%2F100000-tps-over-a-billion-rows-the-unreasonable-effectiveness-of-sqlite.html%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/0100019ae41b5d32-e397873b-baf2-4ccb-8078-1dea7997e506-000000/5p6Upt28Il-7Bx3qRnQOTeDWUTTHs7JDYpEdqk-w02U=434
summary: 100,000 TPS over a billion rows: the unreasonable effectiveness of SQLite (8 minute read) SQLite can achieve extremely high transaction throughput on a single machine because eliminating network latency and using a single-writer model enables batching and efficient concurrency with readers. In contrast, network databases like Postgres hit hard limits from latency and contention, showing that SQLite's ‚Äúlimitations‚Äù are actually strengths for many real-world workloads.

title: Bet the farm
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-03, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwriting.nikunjk.com%2Fp%2Fbet-the-farm%3Futm_source=tldrfounders/1/0100019ae455051f-bd99e17a-87c6-42f4-887c-6f6ebf2ab012-000000/q9rRg4GQbXQ_gFfLjc3Amk-JbGNza7V1im4J734ZlAc=434
summary: Bet the farm (3 minute read) Many companies are bragging about wide-scale AI adoption, but their hallway conversations tell a different story: many employees haven't opened AI tools in weeks. Dashboards are showing logins, not usage. This is transformation theater. Companies that go all in on AI by making it mandatory tell a different story: increased revenue and lower headcount. The best people see the theater and leave for places where transformation is real.

title: The Age of Scaling Is Over!

title: The Awkward Exit: $150M to $300M Acquisitions
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-03, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.mostlymetrics.com%2Fp%2Fthe-awkward-exit-150m-to-300m-acquisitions%3Futm_source=tldrfounders/1/0100019ae455051f-bd99e17a-87c6-42f4-887c-6f6ebf2ab012-000000/LddS8EN9EKliwItXcee2tOr0SmIgmKVjulZhtYv1-_g=434
summary: The Awkward Exit: $150M to $300M Acquisitions (5 minute read) A $200M exit is often life-changing for a founder but a failure for a Series C investor. This "Grey Zone" creates boardroom deadlock. Early investors (Seed/Series A) are happy with a 5x return, while late-stage funds that underwrote a $1B outcome may block the sale to avoid a write-down. The solution: negotiate secondary sales during your growth rounds.

title: Thoughts on AI progress
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-03, Reading time: 14 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.dwarkesh.com%2Fp%2Fthoughts-on-ai-progress-dec-2025%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019ae4942089-056b3ae6-4c19-4178-9a46-9bb0d0d00e42-000000/6XYmCW093kM3REYf07UTvX4djvVjvlPf7dQEaR0lRNg=434
summary: Thoughts on AI progress (Dec 2025) (14 minute read) The driver for further improvement will be continual learning. Solving continual learning will require incremental improvements, just like solving in-context learning. Labs will likely release something next year that they will call continual learning, but it will just be progress towards continual learning. Human-level continual learning may take another five to ten years of further progress.

title: My Favorite Principle

summary: My Favorite Principle (4 minute read) "Levo's Principle" states that an object's behavior should remain constant after construction to improve code clarity, reduce bugs, and simplify refactoring. title: Should CSS be Constraints?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-04, Reading time: 10 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fpavpanchekha.com%2Fblog%2Fwhy-css-bad.html%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019ae943e5e6-8ee22876-7dbe-493c-87e0-0533a99a9978-000000/SlQlAoziyB1E4W373Xv642V9T01_5OOEKoyONWdUnAQ=434
summary: Should CSS be Constraints? (10 minute read) CSS layout rules are complex and hard to pick up just from examples. One commonly-proposed replacement for CSS is a constraint system. Rule-based systems can be complex and hard to predict, but it is almost impossible to create a layout that is not under- or over-determined. A better way to improve CSS would be to provide more intuitive rule systems with more predictable, less esoteric rules.

title: Defining Reinforcement Learning Down
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-04, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.argmin.net%2Fp%2Fdefining-reinforcement-learning-down%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019ae9d6d9a1-05f46ead-87a0-49b5-920c-df8a05d4db02-000000/aak_04oJLVrecLe3oamFoSK8V7sysj9FCic70PxgvaY=434
summary: Defining Reinforcement Learning Down (4 minute read) Reinforcement learning (aka post-training) is simpler than it sounds: generate responses, get scores, then retrain while emphasizing the high-scoring ones. If you already have code to pretrain a model, you can turn it into post-training code by adding a single line that weights updates by score.

title: How confessions can keep language models honest
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-04, Reading time: 10 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2FOB7Aqt/1/0100019ae9d6d9a1-05f46ead-87a0-49b5-920c-df8a05d4db02-000000/CoHoCvI3G3fvU0uXlQkXbZeoPPx1zI5ifRJLdxirIUc=434
summary: How confessions can keep language models honest (10 minute read) When models optimize for correctness, helpfulness, and safety all at once, they can learn shortcuts to ‚Äúreward hack‚Äù while hiding misbehavior in plausible-looking outputs. OpenAI trained a version of GPT-5 to produce a separate "confession" judged only on honesty and found models will admit to reward hacking 90% of the time, even when they hide it in their primary response.

It enables engineers to build adaptive, intelligent apps with streaming, tool calling, agents, and multi-provider support. TanStack AI is a complete AI ecosystem and not a vendor platform - there are no middlemen or service fees, and no vendor lock-in.

title: SVG Filters - Clickjacking 2.0
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 32 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flyra.horse%2Fblog%2F2025%2F12%2Fsvg-clickjacking%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019aee7ce3c5-54d34d99-2ac7-44c4-a917-617fee933856-000000/NkHN5kh3hLV3S-PRNO4D7vgE2sMZ67DiDRAKxCb0128=434
summary: SVG Filters - Clickjacking 2.0 (32 minute read) Clickjacking is a classic attack that involves covering up an iframe of some other website in an attempt to trick the user into unintentionally interacting with it. A new technique called SVG clickjacking turns classic clickjacking on its head. It enables the creation of complex interactive clickjacking attacks, as well as multiple forms of data exfiltration. This article takes a look at the technique and its various applications.

title: Becoming great at listening
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fshreyasdoshi.substack.com%2Fp%2Fbecoming-great-at-listening%3Futm_source=tldrfounders/1/0100019aeea001ce-6f02cf55-211a-4c98-87e8-d5943a045391-000000/4hH7wQ7Ub7laSeFlpuVXT5xiSxsolPFqWkAJWh_t3ck=434
summary: Becoming great at listening (3 minute read) Your job as a listener is to consume decades of someone else's experience in minutes. This is impossible if you are busy mentally scripting your reply. The secret to world-class communication is to treat listening and thinking as mutually exclusive states. Turn off your analysis engine completely while they speak. When they finish, ask for a "thinking pause." That awkward silence is the only way to truly synthesize reality before you act on it.

title: Tether in 2025: A Capital Analysis
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 15 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fdirtroads.substack.com%2Fp%2F67-tether-in-2025-a-capital-analysis%3Futm_source=tldrcrypto/1/0100019aeea04b68-add5b1a4-193c-4c74-801f-bbb2b7fbdaa3-000000/5Jrue5yPxAdqEGyFc9Us7ky8Th5kmThOf7Dj3j07zmE=434
summary: Tether in 2025: A Capital Analysis (15 minute read) Tether is like an unregulated bank rather than a simple money transmitter. Depending mostly on how harshly you treat BTC, Tether's total capital ratio ranges from ~10.9% (OK vs minimal regulatory standards) down to ~3.9% (bad vs market norms). Group-level profits and equity look big, but most sit outside the actual reserve entity and aren't legally committed to back USDT redemptions, so they can't be counted as true regulatory capital.

title: PeerDAS: How Fusaka Makes L2s Cheaper
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fthreadreaderapp.com%2Fthread%2F1986678949280391640.html%3Futm_source=tldrcrypto/1/0100019aeea04b68-add5b1a4-193c-4c74-801f-bbb2b7fbdaa3-000000/KvpEMhB7qjP1lc2cRHYtMQwKDOD32XG2tMh0TWuV820=434
summary: PeerDAS: How Fusaka Makes L2s Cheaper (2 minute read) Fusaka's main feature, PeerDAS, changes how Ethereum stores blob data. Instead of every node keeping full copies of each blob, nodes only store a small slice of every blob while still being able to verify that the full data exists. That means the network can safely handle many more blobs per block, which lowers data-availability costs for rollups. More blobs per block means cheaper L2 data and cheaper L2 transactions for users.

title: Frontier AI Models Demonstrate Human-Level Capability in Smart Contract Exploits
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fdecrypt.co%2F350575%2Fai-models-human-level-capability-smart-contract-exploits%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/0100019aeed800f8-e7d24dd5-f51a-4c75-b5d4-1dd422a5ef94-000000/sgwHSGdJAPfiUAa4U1TKncZ0z2oB3xRthrZlSHeAq1A=434
summary: Frontier AI Models Demonstrate Human-Level Capability in Smart Contract Exploits (4 minute read) Anthropic evaluated ten frontier models on a dataset of 405 historical smart contract exploits and found that the agents produced working attacks against 207 of them, totaling $550M in simulated stolen funds. Anthropic measured the model's current capabilities by plotting each model's total exploit revenue against its release date. The models also discovered two previously undisclosed zero-days.

title: Proxyearth Tool Lets Anyone Trace Users in India with Just a Mobile Number
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fhackread.com%2Fproxyearth-trace-users-india-mobile-number%2F%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/0100019aeed800f8-e7d24dd5-f51a-4c75-b5d4-1dd422a5ef94-000000/LglBBQqefCdD6SMPRC9F2s__KoiH_YE4dR2WIoMYjVM=434

title: Google partners with Replit, in vibe-coding push
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.cnbc.com%2F2025%2F12%2F04%2Fgoogle-replit-ai-vibe-coding-anthropic-cursor.html%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019aeef6a1be-c5707be7-2ccc-4e6f-9616-fe892eab8ed9-000000/hV4rXaP4LlEXVEchlw0lP8cIC_XDIx5BhOZIIw94dwA=434
summary: Google partners with Replit, in vibe-coding push (3 minute read) Google Cloud has partnered with AI coding startup Replit to enhance enterprise vibe-coding using Google models. Replit will use Google Cloud services to expand its platform, supporting AI coding for enterprise clients. This collaboration aims to drive Google Cloud adoption and extend AI reach beyond traditional engineers.

title: State of AI
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 90 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fopenrouter.ai%2Fstate-of-ai%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019aeef6a1be-c5707be7-2ccc-4e6f-9616-fe892eab8ed9-000000/O91yur20pWqbkBUWedvTWeLXVpxoubWsjreYfZDmRN0=434
summary: State of AI (90 minute read) This year was a turning point in the real-world use of large language models. The field shifted from single-pass pattern generation to multi-step deliberation inference. The shift up folded so fast that our understanding of how these models have been used in practice has lagged behind. This study leverages the OpenRouter platform to analyze over 100 trillion tokens of real-world AI interactions to see how the technology is being used in the real world. The way dev...

title: We Got Claude to Fine-Tune an Open Source LLM
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 15 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fhuggingface.co%2Fblog%2Fhf-skills-training%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019aeef6a1be-c5707be7-2ccc-4e6f-9616-fe892eab8ed9-000000/7fM5lkEy7jXKCyLK9oIQkFQApXQpX_YOvIbFjhs6nzc=434
summary: We Got Claude to Fine-Tune an Open Source LLM (15 minute read) Hugging Face Skills gives Claude the ability to fine-tune language models. It can submit jobs to cloud GPUs, monitor progress, and push finished models to the Hugging Face Hub. This tutorial teaches readers how it works and how to use it. The tool allows users to train models from 0.5B to 70B parameters, convert them to GGUF for local deployment, and run multi-stage pipelines that combine different techniques.
